content.description: A crag classic.  Begin up steep pockets two lines to the left of Mr. Slate.  A few 5.10+ technical moves leads you to a great rest at the break below the roof.  The crux at the roof (once protected by an ancient drilled pin) is both powerful and technical.  After that the grade backs off a bit to the chains.
content.protection: 8 bolts to chains.  Again, please don't toprope off the chains.
content.location: The third route from the right side of the tower.

content.description: Easy climbing to a hard, crimpy, reachy move at the roof.
content.location: This one is just to the left of Mr. Slate.

content.description: Shark Bait is one of the finer pitches at the Pit, and maybe the best for the grade. Shares start with Purple Shark.Start out a roof which turns quickly into a steep scooped out section of the arete. the low crux is getting to the second bolt, and is some what intimidating, until you figure out the sequence through the myriad of pockets. A couple big moves leads you to the arête and several more engaging moves. At the obvious break, Purple Shark moves out and left, while Shark Bait continues more or less straight up, passing the redpoint crux via positive gastons, side pulls, and a few spiny nubbins.Good consistent climbing for the grade, separated by good rests.
content.location: Starts on steep pocketed face, finishes on the right side of the arête.

content.description:
A linkup of True Value into Shark Bait. Notable for it's rope drag.

 Climb True Value to the bolt below the roof, clip it with the longest runner you own, then traverse left on easy terrain to Shark Bait.

One of Flagstaff's finest for the grade. 

  Purple Shark starts out with a steep section riddled with pockets. Some technical arête climbing leads to the crux boulder problem over the roof, and onto the upper headwall.
content.location: This route starts on the arete and goes left.  It had purple bolt hangers as of Fall 2005.

content.description: Big moves between second and third bolt to a rail. Clip the third bolt then pull crux moves to the anchor
The classic 10b.  This is an awesome route.  Don't let the roof intimidate you, there's holds up there.
content.protection: 9 bolts to chains. Please do not toprope off the anchors. Hang your own draws up there to reduce wear on the anchors.
content.location: This is the rightmost route on the tower.

content.description: Start as per Don't Feed The Agave by traversing in from the left to an exposed first clip.  Do a very difficult standup move past this, then rest up on a ledge.  Clip a bolt at the hanging arete; Agave trends right, Jesus more or less straight up.
content.location: Route is tucked back in on the left side of the Swiss Tower, right of The Abyss.

content.description: The seldom climbed, often neglected, not really classic route that lies in the shadow of the indomitable Mr. Slate.  Just to the right of Slate is a line of bolts ascending to the top of the tower.  Another one of those routes that you climb so you can say yeah, I've done that.  Expect some dirty holds.
content.location: Accessed from the same ledge as Popeye, the start is probably R due to the fact that if you blow the first clip you'll probably take a bit of a tumble.

content.description: Reachy moves up an arete lead to even reachier moves off a ledge.
content.location: Starts on the leftmost arete of the tower just above an agave.

climbs.name: As Nasty As They Want To Be

content.description: Pull a low roof and then an akward mantle onto a ledge.  Finish up a good crack.
content.location: Just to the left of Purple Shark

content.description: Pretty good route.  Kind of funky off the upper ledge, but generally fun moves on steep rock.
content.location: Located to the left of the tower proper with big flakes off a big ledge at about the 3rd bolt.

content.description: This area is sunny until about 1PM.  It can be windy and is usually crowded on weekends and in the afternoons in the summer.  Rock quality is excellent.
